semantic_title: Present on Admission (POA) Indicator Assignment for Obstetrical Conditions
section_path: Present on Admission Reporting Guidelines > Obstetrical Conditions

content.full_text: Whether or not the patient delivers during the current hospitalization does not affect assignment of the POA indicator. The determining factor for POA assignment is whether the pregnancy complication or obstetrical condition described by the code was present at the time of admission or not. If the pregnancy complication or obstetrical condition was present on admission (e.g., patient admitted in preterm labor), assign 'Y'. If the pregnancy complication or obstetrical condition was not present on admission (e.g., 2nd degree laceration during delivery, postpartum hemorrhage that occurred during current hospitalization, fetal distress develops after admission), assign 'N'. If the obstetrical code includes more than one diagnosis and any of the diagnoses identified by the code were not present on admission assign 'N'. (e.g., Category O11, Pre-existing hypertension with pre-eclampsia) (Evidence: pg no: 120, L12-L17)
content.summary: Guidelines for assigning POA indicators to obstetrical conditions based on presence at admission, not delivery status (Evidence: pg no: 120, L12-L13)
key_concepts: Delivery status irrelevant to POA assignment (Evidence: pg no: 120, L12-L13)
Timing of pregnancy complication determines POA (Evidence: pg no: 120, L13-L14)
Multiple diagnoses in obstetrical codes (Evidence: pg no: 120, L16-L17)
Pre-existing conditions with pregnancy complications (Evidence: pg no: 120, L17)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Whether or not the patient delivers during the current hospitalization does not affect assignment of the POA indicator (Evidence: pg no: 120, L12-L13)
detailed_rules.explanation: POA assignment for obstetrical conditions is independent of delivery status during the hospitalization (Evidence: pg no: 120, L12-L13)

detailed_rules.rule_text: The determining factor for POA assignment is whether the pregnancy complication or obstetrical condition described by the code was present at the time of admission or not (Evidence: pg no: 120, L13-L14)
detailed_rules.explanation: POA assignment depends solely on whether the specific obstetrical condition existed at admission time (Evidence: pg no: 120, L13-L14)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If the obstetrical code includes more than one diagnosis and any of the diagnoses identified by the code were not present on admission assign 'N' (Evidence: pg no: 120, L16-L17)
detailed_rules.explanation: For obstetrical codes representing multiple conditions, any condition not present on admission requires POA 'N' assignment (Evidence: pg no: 120, L16-L17)

workflow_steps: Step 2: Determine if condition was present at time of admission
Step 3: Ignore delivery status during hospitalization
Step 4: For multiple diagnoses in one code, ensure all were present on admission
Step 5: Assign 'Y' if present on admission, 'N' if not present or developed after admission

code_categories_mentioned: Category O11 - Pre-existing hypertension with pre-eclampsia (Evidence: pg no: 120, L17)

references_to.title: Same Diagnosis Code for Two or More Conditions
references_to.explanation: Multiple diagnosis concept applies to obstetrical codes

coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient admitted at 34 weeks gestation in active preterm labor
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify preterm labor as obstetrical condition
Step 2: Confirm preterm labor was present at admission

correct_coding.rationale: Preterm labor was present at time of admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L14-L15)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would be incorrect since condition was present on admission
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Confusing delivery timing with condition onset timing

coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient delivered vaginally with second degree perineal laceration
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify laceration as obstetrical condition
Step 2: Determine laceration occurred during delivery, not present on admission

correct_coding.rationale: Laceration occurred during delivery, not present on admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L15)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would be incorrect since laceration was not present on admission

coding_scenarios.scenario: Pre-existing hypertension with pre-eclampsia developing after admission
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient with chronic hypertension admitted for routine care, develops pre-eclampsia on day 2
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify O11 represents both pre-existing hypertension and pre-eclampsia
Step 2: Determine hypertension was present, pre-eclampsia developed after admission
Step 3: Assign POA indicator 'N' because not all conditions were present on admission

correct_coding.rationale: Any diagnosis in the code not present on admission requires 'N' assignment (Evidence: pg no: 120, L16-L17)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would be incorrect because pre-eclampsia was not present on admission
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Focusing only on pre-existing condition, ignoring newly developed condition

breakdown.preterm_labor: Obstetrical condition present at admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L14-L15)
breakdown.admission_timing: Condition existed when patient was admitted (Evidence: pg no: 120, L14-L15)

examples.rationale: Condition was present at time of admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L14-L15)

breakdown.delivery_complication: Occurred during delivery process (Evidence: pg no: 120, L15)
breakdown.timing: Not present at admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L15)

examples.rationale: Laceration occurred during current hospitalization, not present on admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L15)

examples.scenario: Category O11 - Pre-existing hypertension with pre-eclampsia

breakdown.multiple_diagnoses: Code includes both hypertension and pre-eclampsia (Evidence: pg no: 120, L17)
breakdown.mixed_timing: Pre-eclampsia developed after admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L17)

examples.rationale: Any diagnosis in the code not present on admission requires 'N' (Evidence: pg no: 120, L16-L17)

warnings: Delivery status does not affect POA assignment (Evidence: pg no: 120, L12-L13)
Multiple diagnoses in obstetrical codes require all to be present on admission for 'Y' (Evidence: pg no: 120, L16-L17)
best_practices: Focus on timing of condition onset, not delivery timing (Evidence: pg no: 120, L13-L14)
Carefully evaluate each component of combination obstetrical codes (Evidence: pg no: 120, L16-L17)
common_mistakes: Confusing delivery complications with admission conditions (Evidence: pg no: 120, L15)
Ignoring newly developed components of combination codes (Evidence: pg no: 120, L16-L17)
tips: Determine exact timing of each obstetrical condition (Evidence: pg no: 120, L13-L14)
Review combination codes for multiple diagnoses (Evidence: pg no: 120, L16-L17)
implementation_notes: Applies to all obstetrical and pregnancy-related codes
Requires careful documentation review for timing
